c74object.name: bach.mc2p
c74object.description: Converts an llll containing cents into a corresponding llll containing pitches.

method.name: bang
method.description: Perform the conversion on the most recently received input data.

method.name: llll
method.description: The function outputs an llll formatted as the incoming one, but containing the note name instead of each midicents value.

attribute.name: accidentalspreferences
attribute.description:
Sets how non-natural notes should be represented:
- Auto: let bach choose a default representation.
- Sharps: always choose sharp accidentals (more precisely, in general: always choose a representation such that the displayed diatonic pitch is below the actual note).
- Flats: always choose flat accidentals (more precisely, in general: always choose a representation such that the displayed diatonic pitch is above the actual note).
- Custom: use a custom enharmonic table, defined via the enharmonictable attribute.

attribute.name: octave
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to append the octave number to the note name. Defaults to 1 (true). If this is set to 0, then the output is not a pitch, but a symbol containing the pitch string without the octave.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, e

attribute.name: tonedivision
attribute.description:
In the bach environment, the tone division defines the microtonal accuracy of the symbolic representation, by representing the number of steps in which each tone is divided. For the standard semitonal representation (where just sharps and flats suffice), one can stick with tonedivision being 2, meaning: the tone is divided into two semitones. By increasing this value, the microtonal grid gets more dense: for instance, 4 is the quartertonal grid (where each tone is divided in 4 quartertones); 8 is the eight-tonal grid, and so on.
Set tonedivision to 0 (default) in order to perform the conversion at maximum precision.

c74object.discussion: The pitches are inferred automatically from the cents, by snapping it to the nearest element of the current microtonal grid (see the tonedivision attribute), depending on the values of the other attributes.
